div.p: This element in WRITING TEXTUALFEATURES pertains the time in which a fictional story is set relative to the writer's time, not the reader's. It should contain a statement, which may include a specific date like "1789," or general description, "in the future," or should relate to a recognizable event like "after the First World War." N.b. use for works of fiction (including drama and poetry) only, not for history, biography, or travel writing. Encloses a statement, incorporating a tagged date or a broad definition of period. Has no mandatory or optional sub-elements, but one optional attribute, SETTINGDATETYPE, with values of "past," "present," "future," and "ambiguous." Tag as time present only if contemporaneity is in some way relevant, not if itâ€™s merely assumed.

div.codeblock: <tSettingDate SETTINGDATETYPE="future">The novel is set post-apocalyptic Israel.</> <tSettingDate SETTINGDATETYPE="past">This gothic romance, set in the fifteenth-century, features three notable characters.</>

div.p: We are privileging the author's relationship to the setting date. Therefore, 1984 is still a novel set in the future because it was written as such.
